Thank you for providing that information! It sounds like you have a good foundation of fitness from your gym workouts and sports activities. Now, let's break down your goals and create a plan to help you improve your swimming and biking skills for your sprint triathlon.

**Current Fitness Level:**

* Cardio: You're doing regular cardio workouts at the gym and playing sports, which is great. Your 5K time of 32:15 indicates you have a good aerobic base.
* Swimming: You can do laps, but your pace is slow. We'll focus on improving your technique and endurance in the water.
* Biking: You don't have a bike yet, but you're planning to get one soon. We'll assume you'll start with zero biking experience and build up gradually.
* Running: You've completed a 5K, which is a great starting point. We'll focus on maintaining your running fitness while building up your swimming and biking skills.

**12-Week Sprint Triathlon Training Plan:**

To help you prepare for your sprint triathlon, I'll provide a general outline of what your training plan might look like. We'll break it down into three phases: Base Building (Weeks 1-4), Build and Intensity (Weeks 5-8), and Taper and Rest (Weeks 9-12).

**Phase 1: Base Building (Weeks 1-4)**

* Goal: Build endurance and technique in swimming and biking, maintain running fitness
* Workout schedule: 3-4 times per week, with one or two rest days
* Sample workouts:
	+ Swimming: 2-3 times per week, focusing on technique drills and short intervals (25-50 yards)
	+ Biking: 1-2 times per week, starting with short rides (10-20 miles) and gradually increasing distance
	+ Running: 1-2 times per week, with one longer run (3-4 miles) and one shorter run (2-3 miles)
	+ Strength training: 1-2 times per week, focusing on lower body and core exercises

**Phase 2: Build and Intensity (Weeks 5-8)**

* Goal: Increase intensity and duration in swimming and biking, introduce brick workouts
* Workout schedule: 4-5 times per week, with one or two rest days
* Sample workouts:
	+ Swimming: 3 times per week, with one longer swim (400-600 yards), one interval swim, and one technique swim
	+ Biking: 2-3 times per week, with one longer ride (20-30 miles) and one interval ride
	+ Running: 2 times per week, with one longer run (4-5 miles) and one shorter run (2-3 miles)
	+ Brick workouts: 1-2 times per week, combining biking and running or swimming and biking
	+ Strength training: 1-2 times per week, focusing on lower body and core exercises

**Phase 3: Taper and Rest (Weeks 9-12)**

* Goal: Reduce volume and intensity, focus on active recovery and mental preparation
* Workout schedule: 3-4 times per week, with two or three rest days
* Sample workouts:
	+ Swimming: 2 times per week, with one shorter swim and one technique swim
	+ Biking: 1-2 times per week, with one shorter ride and one easy spin
	+ Running: 1-2 times per week, with one shorter run and one easy jog
	+ Rest and recovery: Focus on stretching, foam rolling, and active recovery techniques

**Additional Tips:**

* Make sure to listen to your body and rest when needed. It's better to err on the side of caution and recover than to risk injury.
* Incorporate nutrition and hydration
